name: Great Exceeding / Preponderance of the Great (大過, Dà Guò)

core_meaning.legge_1899_public_domain: Tâ Kwo suggests to us a beam that is weak. There will be advantage in moving (under its conditions) in any direction whatever; there will be success.
core_meaning.normalized_summary: Overload. The main beam is bending. This is an extreme moment that can’t last as-is. You may have to carry more than is reasonable, act beyond normal limits, or relocate your weight so the structure doesn’t snap. Bold, responsive movement — with integrity, not panic — can still succeed, but pretending it's ‘business as usual’ is dangerous.

translations.text: The first SIX, divided, shows one placing mats of the white mâo grass under things set on the ground. There will be no error.

lines.normalized_meaning: Reinforce the weak base with humble care. Cushion what you’re supporting so it doesn’t crack under strain. Quiet, meticulous precaution keeps you out of trouble.

translations.text: The second NINE, undivided, shows a decayed willow producing shoots, or an old husband in possession of his young wife. There will be advantage in every way.
九二：枯楊生稊，老夫得其女妻，無不利。

lines.normalized_meaning: Unexpected renewal. Fresh life grows out of what looked spent. Pairing seasoned strength with new softness/energy is highly favorable.

translations.text: The third NINE, undivided, shows a beam that is weak. There will be evil.

lines.normalized_meaning: Critical stress point. The load is too much for the support in its current state. Collapse is likely if you try to hold this alone.

translations.text: The fourth NINE, undivided, shows a beam curving upwards. There will be good fortune. If (the subject of it) looks for other (help but that of line one), there will be cause for regret.

lines.normalized_meaning: You manage to brace and lift the sagging structure — good. But don’t go chasing extra/outsider help that actually weakens the fix. Overcomplication leads to regret.

translations.text: The fifth NINE, undivided, shows a decayed willow producing flowers, or an old wife in possession of her young husband. There will be occasion neither for blame nor for praise.
九五：枯楊生華，老婦得其士夫，無咎無譽。

lines.normalized_meaning: Late bloom. It looks impressive, but it’s not lasting renewal. It’s acceptable, not glorious. Don’t mistake brief sparkle for true recovery.

translations.text: The topmost SIX, divided, shows its subject with extraordinary (boldness) wading through a stream, till the water hides the crown of his head. There will be evil, but no ground for blame.

lines.normalized_meaning: Total overextension. You push past safe limits for the sake of the crisis and get in over your head. The outcome is harsh, but the motive is honorable.
